thread.title: Over 40,000 North East jobs to be created through remaining in EU, says CBI
thread.title_full: Over 40,000 North East jobs to be created through remaining in EU, says CBI

author: Robert Gibson
title: Over 40,000 North East jobs to be created through remaining in EU, says CBI
text:
Over 40,000 North East jobs to be created through remaining in EU, says CBI 00:01, 21 Jun 2016 Business organisation says Brexit would entail 'pulling the rug out from under our local economy' Shares Get business news by email Sarah Glendinning, director, CBI North East 
The CBI has reinforced its pro-Remain stance in the EU referendum debate by highlighting a potentially huge employment boost of more than 40,000 jobs for the North East if the UK stays within the union. 
The organisation, which provides a voice for employers at regional, national and international levels, has pointed to HM Treasury figures suggesting 41,590 jobs could be created within the coming years in the event of a Remain vote, which would allow the UK to deepen economic ties with other member states. 
The CBI says the North East has already benefited from job creation and growth for more than 40 years as a result of UK membership of the EU, with around 100,000 jobs in the region thought to be linked to exports to the Single Market. 
Around 41,640 are within manufacturing - representing 67% of jobs with the sector here. Remaining in the EU and extending the Single Market could see the creation of an additional 5,640, the CBI argues. 
A further 5,690 jobs could likewise be added to the North East’s distribution and retail sector, within which 12,370 North East jobs are currently reliant on trade with the Single Market. 
In administrative and supports, meanwhile, the current figure is around 9,200. 
Sarah Glendinning, CBI North East director, said: “The UK’s membership of the European Union has been of enormous benefit to the North East for over 40 years. 
“Some of the key sectors that lie at the heart of communities across the region, from manufacturing to retail, rely on our membership of the Single Market. 
“Virtually every economist agrees that leaving the EU would likely cause an economic shock, damaging the North East’s prospects. 
“We’d not only put a dent in what we have now, we’d also miss out on thousands of jobs in the near future, as a result of losing access to the Single Market, pulling the rug from under our local economy. 
“This is why the majority of businesses want the UK to remain inside the EU, to best drive growth, support and create jobs, and increase prosperity for our region.” The European Union debate
